displayed_text: Patient: Yeah ‘cause the ones you gave me you prescribed they was they was they jumped out of my skin. Doctor: What is his uh… Healthcare Professional: Those and morphine sixty Doctor: No he gets a breakthrough also right? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Patient: I shoulda brought the… I shoulda brought the pill bottle with me. Doctor: Yeah, okay. So morphine is sixty huh? Can I stick with the same doses? We don’t need to change anything do we of the pain medicine? Patient: Not right now. Doctor: Okay. So the morning and evening dose you’re taking of the morphine? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. (pause7sec) Patient: Yes. Doctor: How’s your mom doing?

Family Member 1: I’ll call. Doctor: Yeah. All right. Family Member 1: So did W___ then tell you that he's been getting these cramps in his legs? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Okay, that and then number two, he did say you know, his gums are real sensitive, but he never told me. Patient: Oh no, no, no. That was when I was taking the Elida. Doctor: Yep. Patient: Or when I would I brush my teeth. Doctor: Yep. Yep. So is it better now on the medicine? Patient: It’s gone. Family Member 1: So that might happen with this pill now, right? Or we don't know? Doctor: We don't know, anything is possible, but most of it is, you know, it's going to be very cyclical, right? Patient: Right.

Family Member: Well there’s good choices you can make. Doctor: Yeah. (Laughs) Patient: You know and a lot more bad ones. Doctor: That is true. Huh, this makes a lot of sense now. Okay. And when do we expect to leave your dad’s house? Patient: I think we’re supposed to be getting the keys to the house we’re purchasing next week. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But that doesn’t mean we’re moving in next week. Doctor: Okay. Patient: We’re probably going to have some work done. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And stay at dad’s until it’s all done. Doctor: So it might be a couple of months.

Patient: No, I don’t think so. Doctor: Well then next time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh the, I don’t know if they come back yet. I saw that… Patient: And I had a bone density done . And I sent that to her, I don’t know if you saw that? Doctor: Uh and G___ is what kind of doctor? Patient: Uh he’s my oncologist Patient: I’m presuming no. where I uh had the scans done Doctor: I’ll ask about it. My sense is don’t order a lot of those tests because Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: If you not having any bone or physical symptoms If it meets the threshold, they can give you a pill Patient: Yeah, yeah, at the same time, so

Healthcare Professional: Oh they thought it was N___’s car. Doctor: He sort of - sent the text out as if it was his car with a picture of my car. HCP OH! Family Member: His car. Oh my! Doctor: But now he doesn’t have any car because he’s in college. He doesn’t have - HCP Oh okay! Family Member: The Mercedes Patient: He’s lucky he’s having college paid for. Doctor: Yeah I know. Healthcare Professional: He had a Buick Encore; that’s a nice car, too. Family Member: Yeah, that was a beautiful car. Doctor: Yeah, so now he’s. So she was sort of joking that if you get any girls’ phone calls, that’s the reason he’s getting them, not - Family Member: Oh my god! Patient: Yeah, “Mom, can I borrow your car?”

Patient: It paralyzes or something. I don’t like that feeling. Doctor: Yeah. No, I don’t want to wait until you get paralyzed either. Patient: It would be in my arms. Doctor: Right. Patient: It would be in my arms and my feet, my toes. Doctor: Yeah, because, but we don’t want to wait until you know it totally messes up with your… Doctor: …walking and stuff. Patient: It’s coming a long… Doctor: Yeah, yeah, but the cancer has stayed in check for a really long time with the chemo… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …so I think uh so far the chemo has done you good. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Alright. So today we’ll go ahead and I know you gave G____ the list of medications…

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were not keen on getting cut open or getting your bowels or your pee’s re-routed. Patient: I’m really not. Doctor: I know you’re not. Patient: I mean, and they want me to put the bag on. Doctor: I know they do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You would actually get two bags. Patient: F*** you sayin’? Doctor: One pee, one poop. Patient: Oh, hell, no, doc! Doctor: That’s what – this is what I’m sayin’.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.strongly disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Cells. Oh, okay. Doctor: The other immune therapies are more generic. Family Member: Right. Okay. Doctor: So you don’t need specialty whatever. It just knows to try to go to the areas that is deemed cancer. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So that’s the ones you see on TV now- Doctor: No. This is the only one. Right. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: And prostate’s the only one that this is true. Family Member: It’s the only one? Doctor: Now, we are going to move on to those kinds of treatments, but, so far, those ones have not been as successful as it is in other treatments, in other diseases. Family Member: Yeah. Okay. Okay. Doctor: That’s where we’re at.

Patient: Sure. Doctor: And that doesn’t commit us to absolutely do this study or… Patient: Yeah. Right. Family Member: It gets the ball rolling. Doctor: Correct. Exactly. And finding out that information is useful anyway even down the road. Even if you don’t do this particular study. Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. More information is always better. Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Family Member: We will be…I mean it’s hard to tell at this point, but would we be coming back basically the same day? Or no? Doctor: Uh when for uh typically. Family Member: Tuesdays work really well for me because… Doctor: We’ll try and keep it. Family Member: …it’s dead quiet on Tuesday’s you know so that works out real well. But -

Patient: Well then – Doctor: And then we think about what’s necessary. Patient: That’s what the, the doctor at P_ said. Doctor: I know! Patient: He say, he say – Doctor: I talked to that doctor, remember? Patient: Yeah! You told me he talked to you. Doctor: I know. Patient: You say. Doctor: So, I said, I know you. That if we did that and everything else, you would just sort of give up. You’d be like, “I’m done. I can just barely -- my quality of life is here.” But I have to tell you, if you really needed it. One, I think your quality of life would actually be much better because you’d be so symptomatic from that problem, you couldn’t ride your bike. You couldn’t go around the block. You couldn’t do anything! You’d just be soiling yourself constantly! So, if that came to be the issue, you would want it done just to improve your quality of life. Patient: Okay. Listen. Doctor: But I also know that that’s not something you would do proactively because the thought of having a bag scares the heck out of you. I know that. I got it. And now I just threw in two possible bags that’s even more frightening. So, I need you to focus on what we have to do next. We gotta get some systemic stuff swirling through your bloodstream –

Family Member: He’s scheduled today. Doctor: Oh you’re scheduled today, yes. Patient: One o’clock. Doctor: So you’ll get that today but we generally start the, we have to put in for the Zytiga to get approved; we have to put in the chemo to get approved. It takes a couple of weeks to do all that. So we would start all of that sort of in you know mid-January. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. Family Member 1: Yeah, I don’t have any additional questions. Doctor: Great. Patient: There you go. Thank you. Family Member: I have a very basic question. Doctor: Of course. Family Member: What does cure mean?

Patient: Yeah. Yeah. My publicist is very on call. Doctor: Yeah. So anything new going on? Patient: No. I mean as far as how I feel. Doctor: How do you feel? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: No new pains? No new issues urinating? Nothing else? Patient: No. I still wake up a couple of times a night you know and go but uh other than that I’m pretty active, play golf a couple of times a week. You know? Nothing slows me down. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I don’t have any bone pain. Don’t have any muscle pain per se. Uh. Doctor: So today we’re just going to go over stuff. And I, I mean it looks like unfortunately there’s been some changes that probably we’ll, we will have to call off the study. Patient: Oh is that right? Doctor: Yeah. Uh so the PSA to start with went up just a little, uh, so. Patient: It’s up around forty something isn’t it?

Family Member: But I was on a higher dose. You’re saying, uh, a lower dose. Doctor: Yeah. What dose were you on? Family Member: Uh, well, when I, I was diagnosed with Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: They had put me on like, it was like eighty milligrams, but then they brought me down because my face was all ballooned out. Doctor: And so this is five a day, five milligrams. Family Member: Yes. It’s a small dose. Doctor: It’s a small, it’s relatively, it’s enough that, you know, it’s going to probably, well, depends. Some people don’t, some people actually even a little dose, they feel, some people feel like really good on it. They feel like they have more energy. Patient: Right. Doctor: Some people just feel weird. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it’s enough, a small enough dose, that you probably won’t notice it, but.

Family Member: Aside from hormones. Healthcare Professional: So they stay on the hormones. Family Member: Oh. Healthcare Professional: So he stays on the hormones but then we add to it. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Either a second-line hormone like he was talking about that they’re looking at this trial using it earlier. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Or - Doctor: There are six drugs that have been approved by the FDA right now specifically for hormone-resistant prostate cancer. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Two of those six are chemos. One is immunotherapy, one is a bone-targeted therapy for bone metastases and two are pills. So there are six drugs in addition to the conventional, old-fashioned hormone therapy that we only use if the cancer becomes hormone-resistant. Healthcare Professional: And there are other ones in development right now.

Patient: Doc, Doc, Doc, that’s another thing. Doctor: What? Patient: I ain’t going to the bathroom regularly and started taking my stool softeners and then I’m mixing up the what-ya-call-it too. Doctor: Yep, that’s what you gotta do. You want me to put this here? I just gave him the side effect sheet. Patient: I need. Family Member: I was gonna look them up anyway. Patient: Let me say this here, Doc. Let me say this here. Everything that you tell me and you do – Doctor: Mm,hmm. Patient: she goes and she looks up everything Doctor: Perfect. Yes. Patient: You know I’m just surrounded with just good people taking good care. Doctor: People who care. Here’s what I said about the bike trip. It’s up to him really to be smart about it. You know I know he loves it and this is something he just has to work out by himself and also with you guys. There’s no real medical reason technically and it’s gonna take us a week or two to get that medicine, so there’s time. He says he’s not gonna stay down in F____.
